The wines served aboard United's flights are chosen in consultation
with Doug Frost, columnist and author (On Wine, 2001; Uncorking Wine, 1996).
the prestigious James Beard Foundati
and is one of only three people in the world to hold both the title of Master Sommelier
and Master of Wine. Mr. Frost and United Airlines have taken a truly global perspective
in selecting vmes for vour acorecation and enoumeni.
A voire santel
featured wines
Your flight attendant will inform you of today's selections.
Some of these wines may onlv be available on selected flights.
champagne
Pol Roger Brut NV Champagne
Pol Roger enjoys a reputation as one of the most consistent producers in Champagne,
creating a sparkling wine that is wildly rich and still balanced. That balance allows play
between fruitiness and earthiness: nutty, rich and juicy, with toast, pear and apple flavors
at the very long end
Pommery Brut Royal NV Champagne
Pommery creates one of the most elegant of Champagnes, and their Brut Royal
always exhibits grace and sottness. Elegance doesn't have to preclude complexty:
their class whe snows cente oear, lemon and earn tavors.
White Wine
Labouré-Roi 2004 Chablis (Chardonnay)
Where California goes for the richness of buttered toast with its Chardonnays, Chablis (a
subregion of Burgundy) is poised, earthy and tart with orange and green apple aromas.
Domaine Vincent Sauvestre 2004 Chablis (Chardonnay)
Chardonnay is a chameleon of a grape; in California and Australia, it can be gooey and
buttery. But the producers in Chablis (a subregion of Burgundy seem unconcerned with

Lockwood Merlot 2002 Monterey
